chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Intranasal corticosteroid treatment
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people receiving intranasal corticosteroids in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I consider when initiating intranasal corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Intranasal corticosteroids are available as drops and sprays. The risk of systemic adverse effects is greater with drops (as they are more likely to be administered incorrectly, resulting in greater systemic bioavailability of the corticosteroid). 
  • The intranasal corticosteroids that are available in the UK are equally effective.
    • However, for children, consider prescribing a preparation other than twice-daily beclometasone, which may suppress growth more than other intranasal corticosteroids (such as fluticasone, mometasone, or triamcinolone). Nevertheless, prolonged treatment with other corticosteroid preparations has the potential to suppress growth in children. 
      • Monitor the height of children receiving prolonged treatment with intranasal corticosteroids. If growth suppression is suspected, consider referral to a paediatrician.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the British Society of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) BSACI guideline for the diagnosis and management of allergic and non-allergic rhinitis (revised edition 2017; first edition 2007) [Scadding, 2017], the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020], and a Cochrane systematic review Different types of intranasal steroids for chronic rhinosinusitis [Chong et al, 2016].

Choosing an intranasal corticosteroid
  • A Cochrane systematic review that assessed the effects of different types of intranasal steroids in people with chronic rhinosinusitis found insufficient evidence to suggest that one type of intranasal steroid is more effective than another in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis, nor that the effectiveness of a spray differs from an aerosol. No studies were identified that compared drops with spray [Chong et al, 2016]. 
  • There is similar clinical efficacy for all intranasal corticosteroids, but bioavailability varies considerably. Factors that need to be considered when choosing an intranasal corticosteroid include systemic drug bioavailability, safety, cost, and ease of device use [Scadding, 2017]. 
Intranasal corticosteroids and growth suppression in children
  • Systemic absorption is negligible with mometasone furoate and fluticasone furoate, modest for other corticosteroids, and highest for betamethasone [Scadding, 2017; Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].
    • Mometasone and fluticasone are favoured for use in children [Scadding, 2017].
  • Several small studies have compared intranasal corticosteroids with placebo in children with allergic rhinitis.
    • These studies show that twice daily beclometasone can slow growth velocity in children, whilst once daily mometasone, triamcinolone, fluticasone, and budesonide do not affect growth. However, it is not known whether once daily beclometasone also affects growth [Schenkel, 2000; Skoner, 2000; Allen, 2002; Ober, 2004; Murphy, 2006].
  • However, other studies have shown that, over a 12-month period, the use of once daily fluticasone in children aged 5–8 years (n = 186) [Lee, 2014], and once daily triamcinolone in children aged 3–9 years (n = 1078) [Skoner, 2015], may result in a small reduction in growth velocity. 
  • The height of children receiving prolonged treatment with intranasal corticosteroids should be monitored. If growth suppression is suspected, referral to a paediatrician should be considered [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What contraindications are associated with intranasal corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe intranasal corticosteroids to people:
    • With untreated fungal, bacterial, or viral nasal infections. 
    • After recent nasal surgery, or trauma, unless on specialist advice. 
      • Intranasal corticosteroids can be used after healing has occurred.
    • Pulmonary tuberculosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020] and the manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics for Flixonase [ABPI, 2019b], Beconase [ABPI, 2019a], and Nasonex [ABPI, 2020c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Can I prescribe intranasal corticosteroids to a woman who is pregnant or breastfeeding?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Pregnancy
    • Intranasal corticosteroids can be used in pregnancy.
  • Breastfeeding
    • Intranasal corticosteroids can be used during breastfeeding.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Pregnancy
  • This recommendation is based on the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020], manufacturer's summaries of product characteristics, the UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) monograph Corticosteroids in pregnancy [UKTIS, 2016b], and a systematic review Safety of intranasal corticosteroid sprays during pregnancy: an updated review [Alhussien, 2017]. 
    • A systematic review found no significant link with congenital organ malformations and intranasal use of beclomethasone, budesonide, fluticasone propionate, fluticasone furoate, or mometasone. However, intranasal triamcinolone was found to have a significant association with respiratory tract defects [Alhussien, 2017]. 
    • Manufacturers of Beconase, Flixonase, and Nasonex advise that there is inadequate evidence of safety in human pregnancy and highlight an association between relatively high systemic exposure and birth defects in animals, however, they state that direct intranasal application ensures minimal systemic exposure, but they should not be used unless the potential benefits outweigh the possible risks [ABPI, 2019a; ABPI, 2019b; ABPI, 2020c]. 
    • The UKTIS monograph on oral corticosteroids states that currently available data do not suggest that first trimester exposure to systemic corticosteroids in pregnancy increases the overall risk of congenital abnormalities, such as cleft lip/palate [UKTIS, 2016b]. 
Breastfeeding
  • This recommendation is based on the Specialist Pharmacy Service (SPS) document Safety in lactation: drugs used in nasal allergy [SPS, 2016b], the Drugs and Lactation Database (LactMed), and manufacturer's summaries of product characteristics for Beconase, Flixonase, and Nasonex.
    • Drugs used for nasal allergy have limited systemic absorption in the mother, and pose negligible risk to a breastfed infant. There is no published evidence of safety or milk levels for any of the listed drugs when used intranasally [SPS, 2016b].
    • The amounts of inhaled and nasal corticosteroids absorbed into the maternal bloodstream and excreted into breastmilk are probably too small to affect a breastfed infant [LactMed, 2020]. 
    • Manufacturers of Beconase [ABPI, 2019a] and Flixonase [ABPI, 2019b] advise that there is low potential for significant levels in breast milk, while the manufacturer of Nasonex [ABPI, 2020c] advises that a decision must be made whether to discontinue breastfeeding or to discontinue Nasonex, taking into account the benefits of breastfeeding for the child and the benefit of therapy for the woman.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of intranasal corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Local adverse effects of intranasal corticosteroids include: 
    • Nasal dryness, irritation, and nosebleeds.
    • Throat dryness, throat irritation.
    • Skin erythema, rash, itching.
    • Headache, disturbance of smell and taste.
    • Nasal burning, irritation, ulceration. 
  • Systemic adverse effects — these occur rarely, are much less likely to occur than with oral corticosteroids, and are associated with high doses or prolonged treatment. The risk is higher with drops compared with sprays, as they are administered incorrectly more frequently. 
  • Systemic adverse effects include:
    • Adrenal suppression — for signs and symptoms of adrenal suppression, see the section on Adrenal insufficiency in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral.
    • Cushing's syndrome.
    • Decreased bone mineral density.
    • Increased intraocular pressure, glaucoma, cataract, blurred vision, central serous chorioretinopathy.
      • If a person presents with symptoms such as blurred vision or other visual disturbances, consider referral to an ophthalmologist for evaluation. 
    • Psychological and behavioural effects (such as psychomotor hyperactivity, sleep disorders, anxiety, depression, and aggression [particularly in children]).
    • Growth suppression.
  • For more information on the systematic adverse effects of corticosteroids, see the section on Adverse effects in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This information is largely based on the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020] and the manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics for Flixonase [ABPI, 2019b], Beconase [ABPI, 2019a], and Nasonex [ABPI, 2020c].

Systemic adverse effects
  • The extent of systemic absorption varies between steroids: mometasone furoate and fluticasone have negligible systemic absorption, others have modest absorption, whilst betamethasone has high systemic absorption [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]. 
  • The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) advises that psychological and behavioural adverse effects of oral corticosteroids may also occur with nasal corticosteroids [MHRA, 2010].
  • Central serous chorioretinopathy has been reported after intranasal administration of corticosteroids [MHRA, 2017].
Ocular adverse effects
  • Manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics list glaucoma and raised intraocular pressure as very rare adverse effects. However, a systematic review and meta-analysis found that inhaled corticosteroids do not lead to clinically significant ocular changes [Valenzuela, 2019].
  • A MHRA Drug Saftey update advises that there is a rare risk of central serous chorioretinopathy with local as well as systemic administration of corticosteroids [MHRA, 2017]. 
    • People should be advised to report any blurred vision or other visual disturbances during corticosteroid treatment.
Intranasal corticosteroids and growth suppression in children
  • Systemic absorption is negligible with mometasone furoate and fluticasone furoate, modest for other corticosteroids, and highest for betamethasone [Scadding, 2017; Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].
    • Mometasone and fluticasone are favoured for use in children [Scadding, 2017].
  • Several small studies have compared intranasal corticosteroids with placebo in children with allergic rhinitis.
    • These studies show that twice daily beclometasone can slow growth velocity in children, whilst once daily mometasone, triamcinolone, fluticasone, and budesonide do not affect growth. However, it is not known whether once daily beclometasone also affects growth [Schenkel, 2000; Skoner, 2000; Allen, 2002; Ober, 2004; Murphy, 2006].
  • However, other studies have shown that, over a 12-month period, the use of once daily fluticasone in children aged 5–8 years (n = 186) [Lee, 2014], and once daily triamcinolone in children aged 3–9 years (n=1078) [Skoner, 2015], may result in a small reduction in growth velocity. 
  • The height of children receiving prolonged treatment with intranasal corticosteroids should be monitored. If growth suppression is suspected, referral to a paediatrician should be considered [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I minimize the risks of adverse effects in people using intranasal corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• To minimize the adverse effects of intranasal corticosteroids:
    • Prescribe a nasal spray instead of drops. 
    • Prescribe the weakest potency possible, for the shortest period of time.
    • Prescribe a benzalkonium free preparation for people who experience nasal irritation (for example, Flixonase Nasules). 
    • Provide advice about using the correct technique to apply corticosteroid drops and sprays.
  • In children receiving prolonged treatment with high doses of intranasal corticosteroids (especially drops):
    • Consider prescribing a preparation other than twice daily beclometasone.
    • Monitor height regularly, using a growth chart. Any slowing of growth rate should prompt a reduction in dose if possible, or referral to a paediatrician.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Techniques
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Nasal spray technique
  • Advise the person to:
    • Gently blow the nose to clear it.
    • Shake the bottle well and take off the dust cap.
    • Close off one nostril and put the nozzle in the other. Tilt the head forward slightly and keep the bottle upright.
    • Breathe in slowly through the nose and at the same time squeeze a fine mist into the nose, but avoid sniffing. 
    • Breathe out through the mouth.
    • If two sprays are required in both nostrils, take a second spray in the same nostril then repeat this procedure for the other nostril.
Nasal drops technique
  • Advise the person to:
    • Gently blow the nose to clear it.
    • While standing up, bend right over — if they can not do this, advise them to kneel down and then bend right over.
    • Put the opened container into one nostril and gently squeeze.
    • Keep squeezing until the sides of the container touch each other — this will mean that about half the dose has been given (about 6 drops).
    • Repeat this step to use the remainder in the other nostril.
    • Stay with the head down for at least 1 minute after putting the drops in.
  • If they are unable to manage either of these techniques, advise them instead to:
    • Lie on their back on a bed with the head tilted over the edge.
    • Apply the drops.
    • Then, rest their head sideways on the bed for at least 1 minute.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the British Society of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) BSACI guideline for the diagnosis and management of allergic and non-allergic rhinitis (revised edition 2017; first edition 2007) [Scadding, 2017], the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020], and patient information leaflets for Flixonase Nasules [ABPI, 2012] and Flixonase Aqueous Nasal Spray [ABPI, 2019d].

  • Systemic absorption is negligible with mometasone furoate and fluticasone furoate, modest for other corticosteroids, and highest for betamethasone [Scadding, 2017; Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].
    • Mometasone and fluticasone are favoured for use in children [Scadding, 2017].
  • The height of children receiving long term intranasal corticosteroids should be monitored. If growth is slowed, treatment should be reviewed and referral to a paediatrician considered [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give to a person receiving intranasal corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person that: 
    • Intranasal corticosteroids should be used regularly, once or twice daily, for effective control of symptoms.
    • They may not notice any benefit from the treatment for a few days, and maximal effect may not be apparent until after a few weeks. 
    • Intranasal corticosteroids (especially drops) should be used correctly to avoid systemic absorption and adverse effects.
    • They should stop using the intranasal corticosteroid if they experience local adverse effects (such as nosebleeds or nasal irritation).
      • Treatment can be restarted when adverse effects settle. However, if this occurs regularly, they should seek medical advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the British Society of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) BSACI guideline for the diagnosis and management of allergic and non-allergic rhinitis (revised edition 2017; first edition 2007) [Scadding, 2017] and the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

  • The recommendation to stop intranasal corticosteroids if local adverse effects occur, and restart treatment when adverse effects settle, is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
